Executive Summary-amended
                            Puma Energy Caribe, LLC
                           Puma Bayamon LPG Terminal
                              Risk Management Plan


Puma Energy Caribe, LLC (Puma) is currently performing butane and propane storage and truck loading activities at its terminal site located at State Road #28, km. 0.2, Bayamon, Puerto Rico.  The Terminal is using the Guaynabo Puma dock facilities to receive and ship product. Puma is required to comply with United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68 because the facility stores propane and butane on-site in quantities exceeding the rule threshold quantity for these substances.  The following executive summary is provided in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.155.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Puma is committed to operating and maintaining its butane and propane operations (generically referred to as liquefied petroleum gas or LPG) in a safe and responsible manner.  Puma has developed and implemented accidental release prevention and emergency response provisions at the facility, including those required under the USEPA RMP rule and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The facility is also subject to other emergency plan regulations such as those under the Oil Pollution Act (OPA) of 1990, state Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (ECPRA), and United States Coast Guard (USCG) rules.

Management of Change - Written procedures are used to manage changes to process-related chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures, and other changes that may affect a regulated process.
Pre-Startup Review - Reviews are conducted for new or significantly modified processes to ensure the facilities and processes are adequate and safe for operation.
Compliance Audits - Periodic audits are conducted at least every three years to verify compliance with RMP requirements, with prompt and appropriate responses following any finding and deficiencies identified during the audit.
Incident Investigation - Incidents that result in or could reasonably result in catastrophic releases of butane or propane will be investigated within 48 hours of an incident, and findings will be addressed promptly.
Employee Participation - The facility has a program for involvement of employees in conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other process safety management elements.
Hot Work Permit - Permits will be required and issued for hot work operations conducted on or near a butane or propane process.
Contractor Safety - The facility has a program to evaluate contractors and ensure that contractors are properly trained, informed of all hazards, and performing work in a safe manner.

Five-year Accident History
PUMA Energy Caribe, LLC, purchased the Facility on May 11, 2011, which includes the LPG (Propane & Butane) facilities. The LPG consists of 25 existing bullet tanks, and one existing (1) Sphere. The existing butane and propane bullets were upgraded and processes and safety system are newly built. Emergency Response Program
The facility has developed an emergency response program, including a written emergency response plan with notification, emergency medical treatment, and emergency response procedures.

Planned Changes to improve Safety
PUMA continually strives to improve process safety. The facility's butane and propane processes are newly built and designed in accordance with recognized safety industry standards and/or government requirements. PUMA expects that on-going programs such as process hazard analyses, compliance audits, and incident investigations will result in continual improvements to process safety.
